image.altText: Israeli soldiers walk on grassy terrain.

items.synopsis: Israel says its infantry and tanks have carried out raids inside the Gaza Strip, its first announcement of a shift from an air war to ground operations to root out Hamas fighters a week after their deadly rampage in southern Israel.

title.children: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: A moment decades in the making: It's time for Australians to cast their votes on a new Voice

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

items.synopsis: A No vote — and how we got to one — will change the way we see ourselves, and send the most unloving of messages to Indigenous Australians, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: A prediction made 12 months ago is coming true — and it's sending a painful message

image.altText: Two young men are silhouetted on a city street as they walk beside flames burning on the ground after a protest.

items.synopsis: Israeli ground forces have made raids into Gaza over the past 24 hours, the military says, ahead of an expected ground offensive on the densely populated Palestinian territory.

title.children: Middle East on a knife's edge as Israeli ground invasion of Gaza looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters is reporting that one of its news videographers, Issam Abdallah, was killed on Friday while working in southern Lebanon. The news agency says it is seeking more information and working with the authorities in the region. Earlier, Reuters reported that Israeli shelling had struck a Lebanese army observation post at the border. The Israeli military said it fired in response to a suspected armed infiltration, which it later said had been a false alarm. Israel's UN envoy, Gilad Erdan, said it would investigate what had happened in the area following the journalist's death. "We always try to mitigate and avoid civilian casualties. Obviously, we would never want to hit or kill or shoot any journalist that is doing its job," Mr Erdan said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reuters journalist killed in southern Lebanon

children.content: Reuters is reporting that one of its news videographers, Issam Abdallah, was killed on Friday while working in southern Lebanon.
The news agency says it is seeking more information and working with the authorities in the region.

props.alt: A middle-aged man with a beard, sunglasses and camera stands on a ruined city street, looking at the camera.

children.content: Issam Abdallah takes a selfie while working in Turkey in February.
(Reuters)
Earlier, Reuters reported that Israeli shelling had struck a Lebanese army observation post at the border.
The Israeli military said it fired in response to a suspected armed infiltration, which it later said had been a false alarm.
Israel's UN envoy, Gilad Erdan, said it would investigate what had happened in the area following the journalist's death.
"We always try to mitigate and avoid civilian casualties. Obviously, we would never want to hit or kill or shoot any journalist that is doing its job," Mr Erdan said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Palestinians have been fleeing south from Gaza City and nearby towns after Israel issued its warning to civilians to evacuate northern Gaza on Friday. About half the tiny territory's population lives in the north, meaning Israel's warning affects roughly 1.1 million people. Hamas has urged Gazans not to comply with Israel's evacuation order, but the Associated Press reports it has not made any attempts to prevent the mass exodus. Men, women and children could be seen packed together on the back of trucks and bikes along with household possessions as long lines of vehicles stretched out of the territory's capital.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinians flee northern Gaza ahead of Israeli deadline

children.content: Palestinians have been fleeing south from Gaza City and nearby towns after Israel issued its warning to civilians to evacuate northern Gaza on Friday.
About half the tiny territory's population lives in the north, meaning Israel's warning affects roughly 1.1 million people.

props.alt: A city street is packed with cars as smoke rises from buildings in the background.

children.content: Palestinian civilians flee Gaza City on Friday after Israel's warning.
(AP Photo)
Hamas has urged Gazans not to comply with Israel's evacuation order, but the Associated Press reports it has not made any attempts to prevent the mass exodus.
Men, women and children could be seen packed together on the back of trucks and bikes along with household possessions as long lines of vehicles stretched out of the territory's capital.

props.alt: Palestinian men, women and children packed into the back of trucks in a traffic jam.

children.content: Civilians had little warning to evacuate northern Gaza.
(AP Photo)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The IDF says Israeli ground forces have conducted raids in the Gaza Strip over the past 24 hours, ahead of its expected ground offensive. A statement from the army said it had conducted the "localised" raids to "complete the effort to cleanse the area of terrorists and weaponry", as well as to attempt to find missing people. Hamas militants abducted an estimated 150 Israelis and foreigners during their terror attack in southern Israel last weekend. Read the full story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli troops conduct early ground raids into Gaza

featuredLink.title: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

props.alt: Two soldiers jog on a street as a large armoured vehicle kicks up dust in the background.

children.content: An Israeli armoured personnel carrier drives near the Gaza border on Friday.
(Reuters)
The IDF says Israeli ground forces have conducted raids in the Gaza Strip over the past 24 hours, ahead of its expected ground offensive.
A statement from the army said it had conducted the "localised" raids to "complete the effort to cleanse the area of terrorists and weaponry", as well as to attempt to find missing people.
Hamas militants abducted an estimated 150 Israelis and foreigners during their terror attack in southern Israel last weekend.
Read the full story below.

image.altText: Three posters with photographs of people and the words 'bring them home'

items.synopsis: A week after Hamas terrorists' brutal attack on Israel, up to 150 kidnap victims remain in Gaza. Experts on hostage negotiation and terrorism say the world now faces several difficult choices.

title.children: The world's never seen a hostage crisis quite like this. Here's how it could play out

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation whose mission is to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

image.altText: A sullen man looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: There was a time when the name of one whistleblower was on everyone's lips. Kathy Jackson was lauded as a "revolutionary" — but in the shadows was another person waiting to blow the whistle on her.

image.altText: England's Ollie Watkins slides in to score a goal against the Socceroos.

image.altText: A man in a suit, sitting for an interview with a microphone clipped to his tie.

items.synopsis: In 2021, a doctor and pastor met with his friends in Florida allegedly to arrange the overthrow of the Haitian president. Now Kenya is being sent in to help a country plunged into chaos.

image.altText: composite of fire truck for western australia fire service, people at a beach side pool in sydney and people skiing in perisher

image.altText: a ballot paper is dropping in a sealed ballot box with a purple lid

image.altText: A Cruise driverless taxi in San Francisco

image.altText: A man wearing a suit sits on a stool surrounded by TV camera and lights.

items.synopsis: Anxiety about coming out. Name calling. Feeling you can't be your true self at work. Three LGBTQIA+ journalists discuss some of the hurdles they've experienced in their careers.

image.altText: A composite photo of Ramia Abdo Sultan, left, and Tzipi Cohen Hyams, both looking serious

items.synopsis: Many Israeli and Palestinian people in Australia know someone who has either been killed, injured, kidnapped, displaced, or is in hiding. As the conflict escalates, they fear more bad news.

items.synopsis: Returning to her first professional club Central Coast Mariners, the Matildas forward is ready to answer her critics.

title.children: Kyah Simon wants to banish her Women's World Cup ghosts

image.altText: A woman, a man and two young children look at the camera, surrounded by luggage and other people

image.altText: three men walk out of the kings cross police station after they were arrested for allegedly doing the nazi salute

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi wears a black jacket and pants and brown top and holds a black bag as she walks behind a white car.
